title: 112_s2263
content: The Act is titled the "National Program for Arts and Technology Act of 2012" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as finding and purposes. The "National Program for Arts and Technology Act of 2012" aims to establish a national program to provide grants for qualified centers in impoverished areas to create a sense of belonging and dignity, as well as generate professional job opportunities. The National Program for Arts and Technology Act of 2012 aims to support various stakeholders by collaborating with different organizations, assisting in workforce development, promoting diverse communities, providing job training programs, and bridging the gap between education and lifelong learning through the visual arts discipline. The National Program for Arts and Technology Act of 2012 supports workforce development, diverse communities, job training programs, and education through the visual arts. It also focuses on developing extended day or year programming with local schools to engage at-risk students through applied arts instruction. The National Program for Arts and Technology Act of 2012 focuses on workforce development, job training programs, and education through visual arts. It also aims to engage at-risk students through applied arts instruction. The National Program for Arts and Technology Act of 2012 defines "Center of Origin" as Manchester Bidwell, the model for the program. "Interested communities" are those showing financial support and forming advisory committees with diverse stakeholders committed to the program. The National Program for Arts and Technology Act of 2012 defines a "qualified center" as a private, nonprofit educational entity that operates under the guidelines of the national program, with potential funding identified for Federal matching requirements. The National Program for Arts and Technology Act of 2012 defines a "qualified center" as a private, nonprofit educational entity that provides education and training to underemployed or unemployed individuals in industry-specific job skills, accessible to communities with limited transportation, supports at-risk students, and is housed in a sustainable building. It must have a valid affiliation agreement with the Center of Origin and comply with specific requirements. The qualified center must meet quarterly performance goals related to students' attendance, behavior, retention, recruitment, enrollment, outcomes, and job placement. It must also adhere to essential operating conditions and participate in professional development opportunities. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, who oversees development opportunities for board members, executives, and staff. SEC. 4. GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary will establish a national program for arts and technology to award grants to qualified centers and communities. Funds cannot be used for capital expenditures or endowment gifts, and matching funds are required to be eligible for a grant. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a qualified center or community must provide non-Federal contributions equal to $1 for each $1 of Federal funds received. The application must be submitted to the Secretary with required information on activities to be conducted. The grant application must include a description of activities, specific measurable goals, evidence of community affiliation, and a teaching model consistent with regulations. Each recipient must submit an annual report to the Secretary as required. The annual report must describe progress towards meeting specific goals and objectives outlined in the grant applications. $25,000,000 is authorized for the Act from 2012 to 2016.
